docs.snippet: Cecil Lewis, whose wide-ranging career took him from flying ace to author and from broadcasting executive to Oscar winner, died on Monday at King Edward VII Hospital here, his family said. He was 98.    Mr. Lewis joined the Royal Flying Corps at 1...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cecil Lewis, whose wide-ranging career took him from flying ace to author and from broadcasting executive to Oscar winner, died on Monday at King Edward VII Hospital here, his family said. He was 98. Mr. Lewis joined the Royal Flying Corps at 17. Wounded in action in World War I, he was awarded a Military Cross.
docs.abstract: Cecil Lewis, World War I flying ace, author, broadcasting executive and screenwriter, dies at age 98 (S)þ

headline.main: Cecil Lewis, 98, Pilot In Wartime, Writer And Oscar Winner

docs.snippet: AN ADVERTISING MAN WITH A SALES campaign on his mind called this office not long ago wanting to know what music we listen to while reading our favorite newspaper. At the time, I couldn't bring myself to call him back, but I hope this makes amends....
docs.lead_paragraph: AN ADVERTISING MAN WITH A SALES campaign on his mind called this office not long ago wanting to know what music we listen to while reading our favorite newspaper. At the time, I couldn't bring myself to call him back, but I hope this makes amends. My first answer, Mr. Ad Man, is ''nothing.'' Either you read the paper, or you listen to music. Does one turn the pages of ''A Man Without Qualities'' while making love? Should we tap dance at the dinner table? One plus one only occasionally equals two and is more likely to end up zero.
docs.abstract: Bernard Holland article on his view, as music lover, that listening demands full attention and on contradictory view that music can be background for other activities; drawing (M)

headline.main: Listening Is Either/Or. Or Is It?

docs.snippet: For Pets, at the Plaza   WEDNESDAY -- The Bide-A-Wee Home Association will hold a dinner-dance at the Plaza to raise money for the organization's pet shelters and adoption services. Among those to be honored at the event are Anouk Aimee, the actre...
docs.lead_paragraph: For Pets, at the Plaza WEDNESDAY -- The Bide-A-Wee Home Association will hold a dinner-dance at the Plaza to raise money for the organization's pet shelters and adoption services. Among those to be honored at the event are Anouk Aimee, the actress. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $350, from (212) 838-2660. Civitas at Christie's THURSDAY -- Civitas, the Upper East Side community organization, will benefit from a cocktail party from 6 to 9 P.M. at Christie's, 502 Park Avenue (59th Street). Tickets, $75, or $40 for those under 30, from (212) 996-0745.

docs.snippet: Luciano Pavarotti has not been giving colleagues and listeners his full attention in recent times. Reports from the 61-year-old tenor's recital at the Metropolitan Opera a few weeks ago describe a man indifferent to his material and content with t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Luciano Pavarotti has not been giving colleagues and listeners his full attention in recent times. Reports from the 61-year-old tenor's recital at the Metropolitan Opera a few weeks ago describe a man indifferent to his material and content with the easy acquisition of good will from a host of uncritical partisans. The description will be familiar to anyone who observed Mr. Pavarotti's casual approach to the much-advertised ''Three Tenors'' concert last summer at Giant Stadium. Many Met listeners, moreover, had looked forward to hearing Mr. Pavarotti for the first time in ''La Forza del Destino'' this January, but on Thursday it was ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' instead. The singer, a prolific canceller during his mature career, announced earlier in the season that he had not the time or the will -- or who knows, perhaps the ability -- to learn a new part at this stage of his career.
docs.abstract: Bernard Holland reviews Metropolitan Opera performance of Un Ballo in Maschera, starring Luciano Pavarotti and Deborah Voigt; photo (S)

headline.main: At the Met, Deborah Voigt And a Kingly Pavarotti

docs.snippet: A survey conducted after Super Bowl XXXI showed that Pepsi-Cola was the most-recalled advertiser.    The nationwide telephone poll was conducted on Monday by Saa/Research in Ferndale, Mich. Of the 306 consumers who were asked which commercials the...
docs.lead_paragraph: A survey conducted after Super Bowl XXXI showed that Pepsi-Cola was the most-recalled advertiser. The nationwide telephone poll was conducted on Monday by Saa/Research in Ferndale, Mich. Of the 306 consumers who were asked which commercials they could recall 24 hours after the game, 52 percent recalled spots for Pepsi-Cola, owned by Pepsico Inc. and 36 percent Budweiser beer, brewed by the Anheuser-Busch Companies. Anheuser-Busch and Pepsi-Cola bought the most time during the game.
docs.abstract: Survey conducted after Super Bowl XXXI shows that Pepsi-Cola was the most-recalled advertiser by viewers of the game (S)

headline.main: Pepsi-Cola Tops Super Bowl Ad Poll

docs.snippet: Alan Turing was a British mathematics genius whose work in anticipating the electronic computer and in solving the German ''Enigma'' code during World War II earned him an Order of the British Empire and the enduring praise of Winston Churchill. H...
docs.lead_paragraph: Alan Turing was a British mathematics genius whose work in anticipating the electronic computer and in solving the German ''Enigma'' code during World War II earned him an Order of the British Empire and the enduring praise of Winston Churchill. He was also, quite openly for his time, a homosexual. His fate, like that of Oscar Wilde's a half-century earlier, was tragic. Turing's story was recounted by Andrew Hodges in the book ''Alan Turing: The Enigma,'' which was adapted for the stage more than a decade ago by Hugh Whitemore. ''Breaking the Code,'' as the play is titled, starred Derek Jacobi as Turing, both in London and in a 1987 Broadway run. Now, embellished considerably by Mr. Whitemore and still graced with Mr. Jacobi's bravura performance, ''Breaking the Code'' comes to television, on Sunday on ''Masterpiece Theater.'' Prepare for 90 riveting minutes.
docs.abstract: John J O'Connor reviews Breaking the Code, Masterpiece Theater presentation on Alan Turing, who played major role in breaking the German 'Enigma' code during World War II (S)

headline.main: A Life of Public Service And Private Consequences

docs.snippet: Dr. Lee Willerman, a behavioral geneticist who looked for the ways biology could explain intelligence and mental problems, died on Jan. 10 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 57.    Dr. Willerman died after a heart attack, according to the Universi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Lee Willerman, a behavioral geneticist who looked for the ways biology could explain intelligence and mental problems, died on Jan. 10 at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 57. Dr. Willerman died after a heart attack, according to the University of Texas at Austin, where he held the psychology department's first endowed chair.

headline.main: Lee Willerman, 57, Authority On Genes' Role in Intelligence

docs.snippet: I had tried my best. I wore the chalk-stripe suit. But the verdict was that the shoulders were both too narrow and unnecessarily padded. It turned out that my shirt collar was too low for someone with a long neck. And the one-and-a-half-inch trous...
docs.lead_paragraph: I had tried my best. I wore the chalk-stripe suit. But the verdict was that the shoulders were both too narrow and unnecessarily padded. It turned out that my shirt collar was too low for someone with a long neck. And the one-and-a-half-inch trouser cuffs were deemed meager for someone 6 foot 2 with size 11 feet. But, Alan Flusser said cheerfully, the ensemble I had so carefully planned wasn't a total loss. Mr. Flusser, the fashion pundit and men's wear designer, called the combination of sky-blue shirt, bronze silk handkerchief and navy tie with brown and cream dots a success.
docs.abstract: Article on and interview with men's fashion designer Alan Flusser; photos (L)

docs.snippet: Fakes are a fact of life in the art world. They slip into even the finest museum collections and auction or gallery offerings, usually one at a time.    But on Sunday, some prominent art dealers charge, a Florida auctioneer plans to put not one, n...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fakes are a fact of life in the art world. They slip into even the finest museum collections and auction or gallery offerings, usually one at a time. But on Sunday, some prominent art dealers charge, a Florida auctioneer plans to put not one, not two, but dozens on the block attributed to artists like Piet Mondrian, Georgia O'Keeffe, Jasper Johns and Helen Frankenthaler.
docs.abstract: Some prominent art dealers charge that C B Charles, Florida auctioneer, plans to put dozens of paintings on the block with false attributions to artists like Piet Mondrian, Georgia O'Keeffe, Jasper Johns and Helen Frankenthaler; law enforcement officials confirm that they are on the case; Florida's Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services is also investigating; Charles insists works are authentic; drawings (L)

headline.main: Art Dealers Outraged By Auction in Florida
